Dennis G. Wilson, ISAE-Supaero, University of Toulouse, dennis.wilson@isae.fr

Abstract

Melt ponds are pools of water on Arctic summer sea ice that play a crucial role in the Arctic climate system. Retrieving their coverage is essential to better understand and predict the rapidly changing Arctic, but current data are limited. This study aims to enhance melt pond data by developing a method that segments thermal infrared (TIR) airborne imagery into melt pond, sea ice, and ocean classes.

Due to temporally and spatially varying surface temperatures, a data-driven deep learning approach is used to solve this task. The AutoSAM model, a Segment Anything-based segmentation model, is adapted and fine-tuned for this purpose. The code, data, and models are made available online.

Introduction

The Arctic region is undergoing rapid transformation due to anthropogenic climate change. Temperatures in the Arctic are rising three to four times faster than the global average, a process known as Arctic amplification. Since the beginning of satellite retrievals, scientists have observed a continuing loss of sea ice, with the current rate estimated at 12.7% per decade during summer months. Future projections indicate a summer ice-free Arctic by the middle of this century. These changes have significant implications for local communities and ecosystems.

Melt ponds are pools of water that form on Arctic sea ice as a result of summer ice and snow melt when temperatures rise above freezing. They can cover up to 60% and 80% of the ice area on flat sea ice at the peak of melt, and range in size from square centimeters to square kilometers. Due to their darker color, melt ponds absorb significantly more sunlight than the white sea ice and snow, causing surrounding areas to warm up and leading to accelerated ice melt. Melt ponds also increase the light transmittance of the surface with implications for the under-ice ecosystem.

Accurate measurement of melt pond coverage is fundamental for a variety of climate-relevant tasks, ranging from observing the energy balance at the ice surface to improving coupled local and global climate model predictions and sea ice concentration retrievals. However, observational data to date are limited.

In this study, a newly collected dataset of helicopter-borne thermal infrared (TIR) imagery is used to expand data available for melt pond analysis. TIR measures thermal radiation emitted from the surface, allowing retrieval when the sun is low above the horizon. TIR can also detect melt ponds in winter when they are overfrozen and snow covered.

Prior work in this application domain has mainly used pixel-based and object-based approaches such as thresholding, pixel-based neural networks, edge detection, or combinations thereof. However, temporally and spatially varying surface temperatures hamper the establishment of a fixed set of classification features for TIR images, and a data-driven approach is considered instead.

The goal of this work is to effectively segment TIR images into melt pond, sea ice, and ocean classes. A deep neural network is used as the segmentation tool, as it has been shown to perform well in segmentation tasks. Specifically, an automatic and pre-trained version of the Segment Anything (AutoSAM) model is used as the model base, which is then fine-tuned with the labeled TIR image data for melt pond segmentation.

Methodology

2.1 Data

The dataset comprises helicopter-borne TIR imagery acquired with an Infratec Vario-CAM HD head 680 camera during the PS131 ATWAICE campaign. A total of 16 flights were conducted at an altitude of about 300 m in July and early August 2022, corresponding to the summer melt season.
